Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Using Nanoparticle Oxide Coatings to Extend Cycle Life of Cathode Materials in Lithium-Ion Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to increase the cycle life of cathode materials used in lithium-ion batteries by a factor of ten in high-temperature applications by applying protective nanoporous ceramic coatings. SolRayo will investigate the effects that changing several variables that control the nanoporous structure of ceramic coatings have on the cycle life of cathode materials. Such variables include the amount or thickness of the coating, the pH of the suspension of the coating material, the deposition of layers of different ceramic materials on the cathodes, and different methods for depositing the coatings on the cathodes. The materials to be investigated will include TiO2, ZrO2 and others proposed by our industrial partner.

The broader impacts of this research are that, if successful, this project will improve the cycle life of lithium-ion batteries and allow inherently safer and less expensive materials to be employed. Although lithium-ion batteries have gained wide acceptance in consumer electronic products, their use in other markets has been limited by their lifetimes and safety concerns, particularly in applications at higher temperatures. Improving the lifetime and safety of the materials used in these batteries will enhance their market penetration. Preliminary cost estimates indicate that licensing the coated materials to industry could provide approximately $100 million annually in royalties on sales. This work will also benefit the nation by improving our understanding of nanoparticle coating techniques suitable for a variety of energy storage applications.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Any battery is fabricated using two electrodes, an anode and a cathode. Most commercial lithium-ion batteries employ cobalt-based cathodes. However, the focus for this project was on improving the performance of lithium manganese oxide (LMO) spinels as cathode materials because manganese is much more abundant and hence less expensive than cobalt and manganese-based cathode materials have proven to be safer than cobalt-based materials as well as being less hazardous to human health. One concern when using any type of lithium-ion battery is that its cycle life (the number of times it can be recharged) is often shorter than desired, especially when operating at high temperatures. Many studies have demonstrated that coating the active materials in these batteries with selected agents can extend their cycle life.

 

This project is a collaboration between SolRayo, Inc. and researchers at the University of Wisconsin – Madison (UW) in which nanoparticles of titania (TiO2) or silica (SiO2) were used to coat LMO cathode materials. Specifically, the project was designed to optimize several processing factors involved in coating the cathode particles as well as breaking-in and testing cells containing the coated particles. Variables tested included the amount of titania or silica nanoparticles deposited on the LMO, the firing temperature used to adhere the nanoparticles to the LMO, the method used to deposit the nanoparticles on the LMO, the formulation of the suspension containing the nanoparticles and its effect on deposition, and the rate at which the test cells were charged and discharged. Almost all tests were performed at 55oC (about 130oF). The overall goal was to increase the cycle life of cells containing coated LMO materials by a factor of ten when compared to the cycle life of cells with uncoated LMO.

 

Most tests were performed with half-cells (i.e., cells in which the cathode is the coated or uncoated LMO and the anode is a lithium metal foil, which provides a large excess of lithium in the test cells). While the best cells containing coated materials displayed roughly a factor of three to four increase in their cycle life even when cycled fairly rapidly (a 2C rate) in order to stress the cells, the average improvement was a factor of two. However, it is not clear that the lack of expected improvement in cycle life in these lithium foil half-cells is a direct result of failure of the coated cathode materials because other processes not involving the cathode material can occur in half-cells that cause them to fail relatively rapidly. In spite of not meeting the goal of improving performance by a factor of ten, the data obtained in these tests clarified the effect of many of these variables on the performance of coated LMOs and will lead to the submission of a patent application in the near future.

 

Because of the problems that occur when employing half-cells, commercial lithium-ion batteries are fabricated as full cells in which the lithium foil anode is replaced with a graphite anode. Because full cells do not contain excess lithium, good performance in these cells can only be obtained by carefully matching the properties of the cathode and anode materials. SolRayo has performed some tests with coated LMO materials in full cells but, to date, the results suggest that SolRayo has yet to locate a graphite anode that is a suitable match for its cathode materials. This issue presents a significant problem in commercializing the SolRayo coating technology because large users of lithium-ion batteries are primarily interested in the performance of full cells. SolRayo is actively searching for a smaller but experienced manufacturer of lithium-ion batteries that would be interested in collaborating in an effort to further develop this coating technology.

 ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Any battery is fabricated using two electrodes, an anode and a cathode. Most commercial lithium-ion batteries employ cobalt-based cathodes. However, the focus for this project was on improving the performance of lithium manganese oxide (LMO) spinels as cathode materials because manganese is much more abundant and hence less expensive than cobalt and manganese-based cathode materials have proven to be safer than cobalt-based materials as well as being less hazardous to human health. One concern when using any type of lithium-ion battery is that its cycle life (the number of times it can be recharged) is often shorter than desired, especially when operating at high temperatures. Many studies have demonstrated that coating the active materials in these batteries with selected agents can extend their cycle life. This project is a collaboration between SolRayo, Inc. and researchers at the University of Wisconsin – Madison (UW) in which nanoparticles of titania (TiO2) or silica (SiO2) were used to coat LMO cathode materials. Specifically, the project was designed to optimize several processing factors involved in coating the cathode particles as well as breaking-in and testing cells containing the coated particles. Variables tested included the amount of titania or silica nanoparticles deposited on the LMO, the firing temperature used to adhere the nanoparticles to the LMO, the method used to deposit the nanoparticles on the LMO, the formulation of the suspension containing the nanoparticles and its effect on deposition, and the rate at which the test cells were charged and discharged. Almost all tests were performed at 55oC (about 130oF). The overall goal was to increase the cycle life of cells containing coated LMO materials by a factor of ten when compared to the cycle life of cells with uncoated LMO. Most tests were performed with half-cells (i.e., cells in which the cathode is the coated or uncoated LMO and the anode is a lithium metal foil, which provides a large excess of lithium in the test cells). While the best cells containing coated materials displayed roughly a factor of three to four increase in their cycle life even when cycled fairly rapidly (a 2C rate) in order to stress the cells, the average improvement was a factor of two. However, it is not clear that the lack of expected improvement in cycle life in these lithium foil half-cells is a direct result of failure of the coated cathode materials because other processes not involving the cathode material can occur in half-cells that cause them to fail relatively rapidly. In spite of not meeting the goal of improving performance by a factor of ten, the data obtained in these tests clarified the effect of many of these variables on the performance of coated LMOs and will lead to the submission of a patent application in the near future. Because of the problems that occur when employing half-cells, commercial lithium-ion batteries are fabricated as full cells in which the lithium foil anode is replaced with a graphite anode. Because full cells do not contain excess lithium, good performance in these cells can only be obtained by carefully matching the properties of the cathode and anode materials. SolRayo has performed some tests with coated LMO materials in full cells but, to date, the results suggest that SolRayo has yet to locate a graphite anode that is a suitable match for its cathode materials. This issue presents a significant problem in commercializing the SolRayo coating technology because large users of lithium-ion batteries are primarily interested in the performance of full cells. SolRayo is actively searching for a smaller but experienced manufacturer of lithium-ion batteries that would be interested in collaborating in an effort to further develop this coating technology.
